data.title: Author Book Awards and Recognitions for UK Authors – Book Cave
data.meta_description: Book awards serve as markers of excellence, providing recognition and validation for authors' work. For writers based in the United Kingdom, check out these numerous prestigious awards available to honor outstanding literary achievements.

data.text:
79. Queen Mary Wasafiri New Writing Prize:

This prize, organized by Wasafiri Magazine and Queen Mary University of London, celebrates new writing by unpublished writers from around the world, with categories including fiction, poetry, and life writing.

80. Randall Kenan Prize:

Named after the American author Randall Kenan, this prize recognizes outstanding works of fiction by African American LGBTQ+ writers.

81. Rathbones Folio Prize:

The Rathbones Folio Prize celebrates the best works of literature, regardless of form or genre, with a focus on outstanding literary achievement.

82. Raven Award:

The Raven Award, presented by the Mystery Writers of America, honors individuals or organizations that have made significant contributions to the mystery genre outside the realm of creative writing.

83. Republic of Consciousness Prize for Small Presses:

This prize celebrates independent publishers and small presses that produce innovative and daring works of literature, focusing on quality over commercial success.

84. Rise: A Feminist Book Project:

Rise is a feminist book project that aims to highlight and promote literature that explores feminist themes and perspectives, empowering women writers and readers.

85. Royal Society Insight Investment Science Book Prize for Popular Science:

This prize recognizes outstanding books that make scientific topics accessible and engaging to a general audience, promoting public understanding of science.

86. Saltire Society Literary Awards:

These awards, presented by the Saltire Society in Scotland, celebrate outstanding literary achievements by Scottish writers or works that celebrate Scottish culture and heritage.

87. Sami Rohr Prize for Jewish Literature:

The Sami Rohr Prize honors outstanding works of Jewish literature, showcasing the rich literary tradition and cultural heritage of Jewish communities around the world.

88. Self-Published Fantasy Blog-Off:

Organized by author Mark Lawrence, this competition celebrates self-published fantasy novels, with judges from prominent fantasy blogs selecting the best entries.

89. Sense of Gender Awards:

Since 2001, the Sense of Gender Awards have recognized outstanding contributions to gender-related literature, promoting dialogue and understanding around gender issues.

90. Shirley Jackson Award:

Named after the renowned American author Shirley Jackson, this award honors outstanding works of horror, psychological suspense, and dark fantasy.

91. SI Leeds Literary Prize:

The SI Leeds Literary Prize celebrates emerging Black and Asian women writers based in the UK, offering a platform for underrepresented voices in literature.

92. Siegfried Unseld Preis:

This German literary prize, named after the publisher Siegfried Unseld, honors outstanding works of literature that challenge conventions and push boundaries.

93. Slightly Foxed Best First Biography Prize:

This prize celebrates exceptional debut biographies or memoirs, showcasing new voices in the genre and recognizing outstanding literary talent.

94. Somerset Maugham Award:

Presented by the Society of Authors, the Somerset Maugham Award supports young writers under the age of 35 by providing funding for travel and research to enrich their writing.

95. Stephen Leacock Memorial Medal for Humour:

This Canadian literary award, named after humorist Stephen Leacock, honors outstanding works of humorous literature.

96. Stockport Children’s Book Awards:

These awards celebrate children’s literature, with young readers in Stockport voting for their favorite books across different categories.

97. Sunday Times Short Story Award:

Organized by The Sunday Times in the UK, this award celebrates the art of the short story, recognizing exceptional works of short fiction by writers from around the world.

98. T. S. Eliot Prize:

Established in 1993, the T. S. Eliot Prize is awarded annually to the best new collection of poetry published in the UK or Ireland. Named after the renowned poet T. S. Eliot, the prize aims to celebrate excellence in contemporary poetry.

99. Ted Hughes Award:

Named in honor of the British poet Ted Hughes, this award recognizes excellence and innovation in poetry. It celebrates works that push the boundaries of poetic form and content, including poetry collections, performances, and other poetic endeavors.

100. The Barker Book Awards:

These awards celebrate literature that features dogs as central characters or themes. Recognizing both fiction and non-fiction works, the awards highlight the enduring bond between humans and dogs in literature.

101. The Bookseller/Diagram Prize for Oddest Title of the Year:

Since 1978, this humorous literary award has celebrated the quirkiest book titles published each year. It aims to bring attention to unusual and intriguing book titles across various genres and subjects.

102. The Orwell Prize:

Named after the iconic writer George Orwell, this prestigious award honors outstanding works of political writing. It recognizes books, journalism, and other forms of writing that engage with important social and political issues.

103. The Paris Literary Prize:

Founded in 2010, the Paris Literary Prize is an international award that recognizes unpublished works of fiction. It aims to discover and promote emerging literary talent from around the world.

104. The Story Prize:

Established in 2004, The Story Prize is an annual book award dedicated to recognizing outstanding collections of short stories. It celebrates the art of short fiction and honors exceptional storytellers.

105. The Warwick Prize for Writing:

The Warwick Prize for Writing is an international cross-disciplinary award open to any genre or form of writing. It aims to promote and reward excellent writing in all its forms, including fiction, non-fiction, poetry, and drama.

106. The Writers’ Prize:

This prize celebrates emerging literary talent in the UK. It is awarded to unpublished manuscripts across various genres, providing aspiring writers with recognition and support as they begin their writing careers.

107. Theakston’s Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award:

Sponsored by Theakston’s Old Peculier, a British brewery, this award recognizes exceptional crime fiction novels. It celebrates the best in crime writing and is highly regarded within the genre.

108. Thom Gunn Award:

Named after the American poet Thom Gunn, this award recognizes outstanding works of gay poetry. It celebrates poets who explore LGBTQ+ themes and experiences in their writing.

109. Thornton Wilder Prize:

The Thornton Wilder Prize honors individuals who have made significant contributions to American literature and culture. Named after the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright and novelist Thornton Wilder, the award recognizes lifetime achievement and literary excellence.

110. Tir na n-Og Award:

The Tir na n-Og Award is presented annually to outstanding English-language children’s books with authentic Welsh backgrounds. It celebrates books that reflect Welsh culture, heritage, and landscape, enriching the literary landscape for young readers.

111. Tolkien Society Awards:

These awards recognize excellence in scholarship, writing, and creative works related to the life and works of J.R.R. Tolkien. They celebrate contributions to Tolkien studies and the broader fantasy genre inspired by Tolkien’s writings.

112. Tony Lothian Prize:

The Tony Lothian Prize, administered by the Biographers’ Club, celebrates the best proposals for uncommissioned first biographies. It supports aspiring biographers by providing them with the opportunity to develop and publish their work.

113. UAE International Award for Poets of Peace:

This prestigious award, established by the United Arab Emirates, recognizes poets who use their craft to promote peace, tolerance, and understanding. It celebrates the power of poetry to inspire positive change and foster harmony among nations and cultures.

114. Ursula K. Le Guin Prize:

Named in honor of the renowned science fiction and fantasy author Ursula K. Le Guin, this prize celebrates innovative and visionary works of speculative fiction. It honors authors who push the boundaries of imagination and explore new possibilities in storytelling.

115. W. Y. Boyd Literary Award for Excellence in Military Fiction:

This award recognizes outstanding works of fiction that explore themes related to the military experience. It honors authors who skillfully depict the complexities of war, service, and sacrifice in their writing.

116. Wainwright Prize for outdoors, nature, UK-based travel writing:

The Wainwright Prize celebrates the best in writing about nature, the outdoors, and travel, with a focus on UK landscapes and experiences. Named after the renowned writer Alfred Wainwright, the prize recognizes books that capture the beauty and diversity of the natural world.

117. Wales Book of the Year:

This prestigious literary award celebrates the best books by Welsh writers or on Welsh themes. It recognizes excellence in fiction and non-fiction across various genres, promoting Welsh literature and culture on the national and international stage.

118. Walter Dean Myers Award:

Named after the prolific American author Walter Dean Myers, this award recognizes outstanding children’s and young adult literature that portrays the diverse experiences of young people of color. It celebrates books that promote empathy, understanding, and social justice.

119. Walter Scott Prize:

The Walter Scott Prize for Historical Fiction honors exceptional works of historical fiction set at least 60 years before publication. Named after the Scottish author Sir Walter Scott, the prize celebrates novels that transport readers to different times and places while engaging with historical themes and events.

120. Warwick Prize for Women in Translation:

This award recognizes exceptional works of translated literature written by women. It aims to address the gender imbalance in translated literature and celebrate the diversity of women’s voices from around the world.

121. Warwick Prize for Writing:

The Warwick Prize for Writing is an international cross-disciplinary award open to any genre or form of writing. It aims to promote and reward excellent writing in all its forms, including fiction, non-fiction, poetry, and drama.

122. Waterstones Book of the Year:

The Waterstones Book of the Year is an annual award given by Waterstones, a prominent British book retailer. It celebrates outstanding literary achievements across various genres and aims to highlight books that have captured the imagination of readers and booksellers alike.

123. Waterstones Children’s Book Prize:

The Waterstones Children’s Book Prize recognizes and celebrates exceptional writing for children and young adults. It honors authors and illustrators who have created engaging and impactful works that resonate with young readers.

124. Waverton Good Read Award:

The Waverton Good Read Award is an annual literary prize that recognizes outstanding debut novels by UK authors. It aims to promote new literary talent and encourage reading and discussion within communities.

125. Wellcome Book Prize:

The Wellcome Book Prize celebrates exceptional works of fiction and non-fiction that engage with the themes of health, illness, and medicine. It honors books that stimulate interest and debate around the intersection of medicine, society, and culture.

126. Welsh Poetry Competition:

The Welsh Poetry Competition is an annual poetry competition open to poets from Wales and around the world. It aims to promote and celebrate the art of poetry and provide a platform for both emerging and established poets to showcase their work.

127. Whitfield Prize:

The Whitfield Prize is awarded annually by the Royal Historical Society for an outstanding work of historical scholarship. It recognizes books that make a significant contribution to historical understanding and demonstrate excellence in research and writing.

128. William Hill Sports Book of the Year:

The William Hill Sports Book of the Year is an annual literary award that recognizes the best sports writing and publishing. It celebrates books that capture the drama, passion, and human stories behind sporting events and personalities.

129. Windham–Campbell Literature Prizes:

The Windham–Campbell Literature Prizes are prestigious awards given annually to writers of fiction, non-fiction, and drama. Administered by Yale University, the prizes honor writers from around the world for their literary achievements and contributions to contemporary literature.

130. Wolfson History Prize:

The Wolfson History Prize is a prestigious award given annually to an outstanding work of history, published in the UK. It celebrates books that demonstrate excellence in historical research, writing, and interpretation.

131. Women’s Prize for Fiction‎:

Formerly known as the Orange Prize for Fiction and the Baileys Women’s Prize for Fiction, the Women’s Prize for Fiction celebrates and promotes excellence in women’s writing. It recognizes novels written by women from around the world and aims to amplify female voices in literature.

132. World Book Capital:

The title of World Book Capital is designated by UNESCO to a city that promotes books and reading. It celebrates the power of books to inspire dialogue, foster cultural exchange, and promote literacy and education.

133. Zbigniew Herbert International Literary Award: The Zbigniew Herbert International Literary Award is a prestigious literary prize named after the Polish poet and essayist Zbigniew Herbert. It honors outstanding literary works that embody the values of freedom, tolerance, and respect for human dignity.

This concludes our list of awards for UK authors and books. What do you think? Have we missed any? Let us know in the comments below!

Happy writing,
